custom_item_18.description: Only allow access to required network services
custom_item_18.info:
Unrestricted access to services running on a XenServer host can expose a host to outside attacks and unauthorized access.  Reduce the risk by configuring the iptables firewall to only allow access from authorized networks.

    NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_19.description: The hosts.deny file blocks access by default
custom_item_19.info: Because all addresses are blocked by default only addresses found in hosts.allow are granted access to the server.

custom_item_20.description: The hosts.allow file limits access to the local network
custom_item_20.info: The addresses listed are allowed to access all services on the server.

custom_item_21.description: Identify a network interface to be used for storage access
custom_item_21.info: Network traffic for storage should be segregated from normal VM and management traffic to limit access and ensure reliable performance. Documenting this expectation makes it more likely to be followed.
custom_item_21.solution:
Run the following command using the uuid of the dedicated storage physical interface (pif):\n

xe pif-param-set uuid=other-config:management_purpose='storage'

custom_item_22.description: Use a static IP on the storage network interface
custom_item_22.info: A static IP should be assigned to the storage NIC so communications will not be interrupted during address renewal.
custom_item_22.solution:
Run the following command using the uuid of the dedicated storage physical interface (pif):\n

xe pif-reconfigure-ip uuid=mode=static ip=netmask=gateway=dns=

custom_item_23.description: Disallow unplug detection on the storage network interface
custom_item_23.info: A dedicated storage NIC does not require unplug detection.
custom_item_23.solution:
Run the following command using the uuid of the dedicated storage physical interface (pif):\n

xe pif-param-set uuid=disallow-unplug=true

custom_item_24.description: Use a static IP on the management network interface
custom_item_24.info: A static IP should be assigned to the management NIC so communications will not be interrupted during address renewal.
custom_item_24.solution:
Run the following command using the uuid of the management physical interface (pif):\n

xe pif-reconfigure-ip uuid=mode=static ip=netmask=gateway=dns=

custom_item_25.description: All network interfaces are operating in full-duplex mode
custom_item_25.info:
An interface in full-duplex mode can handle more network traffic, improving service availability and the speed of management actions such as migration and backups.

    http://support.citrix.com/article/CTX117568
custom_item_25.solution:
By default interface speed and duplex mode are automatically negotiated. Before setting these manually, ensure the switch or other device the interface is connected to can support the desired settings. Reconfiguring the management interface requires console access, because SSH connections may be lost. To reconfigure an interface run this command, substituting your desired speed and duplex mode:\n

xe pif-param-set uuid=other-config:ethtool-autoneg='off' other-config:ethtool-speed='<100|1000>' other-config-duplex=''

custom_item_26.description: Disable promiscuous mode on all network interfaces
custom_item_26.info: In promiscuous mode all packets received will be processed by the host or VM, which could expose confidential information.
custom_item_26.solution:
Run the following command for each physical interface (pif), especially those that will host VM guests:\n

xe pif-param-set uuid=other-config:promiscuous='off'

custom_item_27.description: Enable QoS on all VM guests
custom_item_27.info: Quality of Service limits can mitigate denial of service attacks and ensure management access to the host. Though this can also be set with vSwitch, that method is deprecated in 6.2 and will not be available in the future.
custom_item_27.solution:
For each VM guest interface (vif) set the quality of service algorithm and parameters, then unplug and replug the vif. To do so run the following commands:
xe vif-param-set uuid=qos_algorithm_type=ratelimit
xe vif-param-set uuid=qos_algorithm_params:kbps=100
xe vif-unplug uuid=; xe vif-plug uuid=

custom_item_28.description: Enable port locking by default on the VM guest network
custom_item_28.info: Port locking prevents ARP and IP spoofing by unknown or untrusted VM guests. It limits their ability to pretend they have a MAC or IP address that was not assigned to them. This setting is the default for the network. If this is set to locked then each VM must be configured with a list of valid IPv4 and IPv6 addresses. A VM that tries to use an address that is not on its allowed list will not be able to send or receive network traffic.
custom_item_28.solution:
Set the default locking mode for the VM guest network by running the following command:\n

xe network-param-set uuid=default-locking-mode=locked\n
NOTE: Any VM on this network must have an allowed list of IPv4 and IPv6 addresses or it will not be able to send or receive network traffic. See the XenServer 6.2 Administrator's Guide for more information.

custom_item_29.description: Restrict allowed IPv4 addresses used by each VM guest
custom_item_29.info: Port locking prevents ARP and IP spoofing by VM guests. Without it, one guest could impersonate another on the host. This setting lists the allowed IP addresses available for the VM using this virtual interface. If the network default-locking-mode is set to 'locked', a VM that tries to use an address that is not on its allowed list will not be able to send or receive network traffic.
custom_item_29.solution:
Set the list of allowed addresses for a virtual interface by running the following commands:\n

xe vif-param-set uuid=ipv4-allowed=\n
NOTE: This setting is only effective if the network default-locking-mode or vif locking-mode is set to 'locked'.

custom_item_30.description: Restrict allowed IPv6 addresses used by each VM guest
custom_item_30.info: Port locking prevents ARP and IP spoofing by VM guests. Without it, one guest could impersonate another on the host. This setting lists the allowed IP addresses available for the VM using this virtual interface. If the network default-locking-mode is set to 'locked', a VM that tries to use an address that is not on its allowed list will not be able to send or receive network traffic.
custom_item_30.solution:
Set the list of allowed addresses for a virtual interface by running the following commands:\n

xe vif-param-add uuid=ipv6-allowed=\n
NOTE: This setting is only effective if the network default-locking-mode or vif locking-mode is set to 'locked'.

custom_item_31.info: Security log information could be modified or lost if the host is compromised or fails. Send syslog messages to a remote host.
custom_item_31.solution: Run the following commands:\nxe host-param-set uuid=logging:syslog_destination=\nxe host-syslog-reconfigure uuid=

custom_item_32.info: Administrators can make significant changes to a system and their actions must be logged.
custom_item_32.solution: This is not a configurable setting. If it fails consider initiating incident response.

custom_item_33.info: Enabled hosts can run VM guests.
custom_item_33.solution:
A host may be disabled for maintenance, or it may indicate an abandoned host which could be removed. To enable the host run the following command:\n

xe host-enable uuid=

custom_item_34.info: Multiple hosts can be joined to a resource pool to provide redundancy and improve availability of the services provided by the VM guests.
custom_item_34.solution:
Add at least one other compatible XenServer host to the pool, configure shared storage, and then run this command:\n

xe pool-ha-enable

custom_item_35.info:
Auto-start directs the host to start VM guests when the host is restarted or powered on. In XenServer 6.x, the auto-start functionality was removed from the GUI because it interfered with high availability (HA) and produced unexpected results. The feature can be safely enabled in a standalone host from the command line.

    http://support.citrix.com/article/CTX133910
custom_item_35.solution: Disable auto-poweron at the pool level by running this command:\nxe pool-param-set uuid=other-config:auto_poweron=false\nSee the article linked below to enable auto_poweron in a standalone host.

custom_item_36.info: Snapshots can consume system resources, cause performance issues, and may be reverted unintentionally causing data loss. If snapshots are not required or actively used they should be removed.
custom_item_36.solution:
Delete the snapshot by running the following command, using the uuid of the snapshot:\n

xe snapshot-destroy uuid=

custom_item_37.description: Passwords stored in 'secrets' are not visible
custom_item_37.info:
The secrets list stores passwords that are required for remote storage connections or other purposes. These passwords may be visible in clear-text to anyone able to log into the host.

    http://blog.403labs.com/post/57428499719/revealing-xenserver-storage-repository-secrets
custom_item_37.solution: Use generic, least-privileged accounts that only have access to the storage repositories. Never mount storage repositories with a privileged Active Directory account.

custom_item_38.description: Review accounts used to mount remote storage
custom_item_38.info:
The list of accounts used to connect to remote storage should be reviewed. The account names are visible to anyone who can log into the host.

    NOTE: Nessus has provided the target output to assist in reviewing the benchmark to ensure target compliance.

custom_item_39.description: Install a trusted CA certificate on the pool
custom_item_39.info:
Using a certificate on the pool allows encrypted communications with the pool master through SSL. This check verifies that a certificate is installed on the pool. It does not verify whether the issuer is trusted.

    http://www.citrix.com/support/security-compliance/common-criteria.html
custom_item_39.solution:
Copy the certificate from a public or private CA to the pool master host. The certificate must be in Privacy Enhanced Mail (PEM) format. To install the certificate run this command:\n

xe pool-certificate-install filename=\n
For more information see the Common Criteria Evaluated Configuration Guide for Citrix XenServer 6.0.2.

custom_item_40.description: XAPI SSL certificate is in default location
custom_item_40.info: The SSL certificate location for XAPI is identified in /etc/xensource/xapi-ssl.conf. If the default location is not used other checks may not be valid.

custom_item_41.description: Install a trusted certificate in place of the default self-signed SSL certificate
custom_item_41.info:
A certificate from a trusted CA allows for secure identification of the XenServer host to XAPI clients such as XenCenter.

    http://www.citrix.com/support/security-compliance/common-criteria.html
custom_item_41.solution: Replace the default certificate for the host XAPI service, located at /etc/xensource/xapi-ssl.pem, and restart. For more information see the Common Criteria Evaluated Configuration Guide for Citrix XenServer 6.0.2.
